skill.name: biopython
skill.description: Primary Python toolkit for molecular biology. Preferred for Python-based PubMed/NCBI queries (Bio.Entrez), sequence manipulation, file parsing (FASTA, GenBank, FASTQ, PDB), advanced BLAST workflows, structures, phylogenetics. For quick BLAST, use gget. For direct REST API, use pubmed-database.
skill.summary: Primary Python toolkit for molecular biology. Preferred for Python-based PubMed/NCBI queries (Bio.En...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: This skill is documentation with example code. Examples include network access to NCBI, local file I O, and external command wrappers. No obfuscation, persistence, or credential harvesting is present.

content.user_title: Learn Biopython workflows for molecular biology
content.value_statement: Bioinformatics tasks can be complex and error prone. This skill provides clear Biopython patterns for sequences, databases, BLAST, structures, and trees.
actual_capabilities: Show how to parse and convert sequence files with Bio.SeqIO
Explain pairwise and multiple alignment workflows with Bio.Align and Bio.AlignIO
Demonstrate NCBI queries with Bio.Entrez and result parsing
Provide BLAST submission and parsing patterns with Bio.Blast
Guide PDB structure parsing and analysis with Bio.PDB
Describe phylogenetic tree loading and inspection with Bio.Phylo
limitations: This skill provides guidance only and does not execute code
Examples require Biopython and dependencies installed locally
NCBI queries and web BLAST need network access and an Entrez email
Local BLAST and external aligners require separate command line tools

use_cases.title: Learn sequence file basics
use_cases.description: Parse FASTA or GenBank files and understand Bio.SeqIO patterns for ids, lengths, and records.

use_cases.title: Automate NCBI lookups
use_cases.description: Search PubMed or GenBank with Entrez and fetch records for literature or sequence analysis.

use_cases.title: Build BLAST pipelines
use_cases.description: Run BLAST searches and parse results into downstream analysis workflows.

prompt_templates.title: Parse a FASTA file
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to read a FASTA file with Bio.SeqIO and print each record id and length.

prompt_templates.title: Convert GenBank to FASTA
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide a Biopython example to convert a GenBank file to FASTA using SeqIO.convert.

prompt_templates.title: Search PubMed with Entrez
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to search PubMed for a term and list the first five ids, including required Entrez email.

prompt_templates.title: Run local BLAST wrapper
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide a Biopython example using NcbiblastnCommandline to run local BLAST and parse XML results.

output_examples.input: Explain how to parse a FASTA file and list record ids and lengths.
output: Use Bio.SeqIO.parse with the fasta format
Iterate through each record and print record.id
Use an iterator to keep memory usage low

best_practices: Set Entrez email before any NCBI requests
Validate file format strings before parsing
Use iterators for large sequence files
anti_patterns: Submitting BLAST queries without rate limits or contact email
Loading very large sequence files entirely into memory
Running external alignment tools without installing them

faq.question: Which platforms support this skill
faq.answer: It is written for Claude, Codex, and Claude Code with Biopython installed in your environment.

faq.question: What are the main limits
faq.answer: It does not execute code and relies on your local Biopython setup and external tools.

faq.question: How do I integrate it in my workflow
faq.answer: Use the prompts to generate Biopython snippets and run them in your existing Python projects.

faq.question: Does it send my data anywhere
faq.answer: Only example code shows NCBI queries and BLAST web calls; you control whether to run them.

faq.question: What if I get NCBI errors
faq.answer: Check your Entrez email, validate ids, and confirm network access and rate limits.

faq.question: How does it compare to gget
faq.answer: Biopython offers deeper parsing and workflows, while gget is simpler for quick online queries.
